dystopiansushi 160967507138 "2017-05-23 01:15:36 GMT" http://dystopiansushi.tumblr.com/post/160967507138/how-to-praise-writers-and-influence-fics "icybluepenguin:  I’ve seen a lot of posts recently reminding readers to leave feedback on fics
column2: which is great!!  Writers deserve all the love they can get.  Likes
column6: these are the lifeblood of writers.  They are proof that people are reading
column8: and that they want more.   But maybe readers don’t know what to say.  Maybe you’re new to Tumblr
column11: or just not sure how to say what you want to say. Let me start by saying
column12: no matter how popular the blog or how cool you think they are
column13: everyone loves a compliment.  If you’re worried about sounding silly or bothering people
column14: let me assure you- a message will make your writer do a happy dance (depending on the writer
column15: they may actually get up and dance.  I have.) Here’s the basic ways of communicating with writers on Tumblr: Likes and kudos- these are great
column16: they’re the high-fives in this world.  They’re the “hey
column18: because they mean exposure.  More people see the story and that makes us really happy.  A reblog with a comment is amazing
column19: especially one that entices others to read.  These make a writer’s day.Comments and messages- these are the thing that keeps us going.  Most of us have anon turned on- and if we don’t
column20: just let us know you want a private reply.  (And
column21: if your writer has anon off
column22: it probably means they’ve been getting hate and deserve extra love.)Recommendations- recs are like coming in to work to find someone baked your favorite cake and left it on your desk.  Recommendations make your writer feel so loved and valued! So
column24: but what do you actually SAY to writers?  It doesn’t have to be much or take a lot of time. A simple “This is great/funny/hot!” is wonderful.  ""Best fic I’ve read this week!“  ""Funny as hell and cute too.”  ""You have to read this
column25: it’s awesome!“  ""I can’t wait for more of this.”  ""I hope you keep going!“  These are great in reblogs and in messages. Even better is specific feedback.  We love specific feedback
column26: because it tells us what readers liked and what they didn’t.  Want to influence our next fic?  Tell us what you liked about this one and I bet you it will keep showing up!  Specific feedback is just telling the writer what you liked.  It doesn’t have to be long or complicated
column27: either.  (But if you write a lot
column28: we will love you so much.) Was there a character you liked?  Talk about them:  ""I love how you wrote X” “Y was so funny!”  ""OMG I wanted to STRANGLE Q!“  ""You can really feel X’s frustration.”  ""Y has so much depth
column29: they’re a really well-rounded character.“  ""R says so much with so few words
column30: it’s amazing.” What about a part or line you enjoyed?  ""That bit in the park- LOVE IT.“  ""I have never read a better description of a cup of tea.”  ""The way you wrote about his fear
column31: that was heartbreaking.“ Was there a part that made you feel something?  Happy
column34: he’s so broken.”  ""I wanted to jump around when they finally kissed!“  ""This chapter was so tense
column35: my heart was pounding by the end.” Did the characters or plot or setting remind you of your life?  ""I live in Brussels
column36: that’s just how that street looks.“  ""When Y talked about R
column37: I knew exactly how he felt.”  ""You captured that lost
column38: aimless feeling perfectly; I’ve so been there.“ Are there unanswered questions?  Mention how much you want the answers.  ""I can’t wait to find out what’s in the basket!”  ""That was a cliffhanger ending
column39: wow.“  ""How is she going to explain THAT?”  (some writers are touchy about  predicting
column41: so stay away from “I bet he’ll throw that letter out.” or “X is clearly coming back.”) A few closing notes: be enthusiastic if that’s your style
column44: caps!  Tell a writer if you’re rereading their work- very little makes us happier than knowing our writing has the staying power for a second
column47: tenth read.  Did a reread give you a new insight or feeling about the fic?  Tell us!  We will be so excited to hear.  And remember
column48: recommendations are wonderful- putting up a random post tagging your favorite writers or fics you’re enjoying will show the writers that they’re writing is more than a flash in the opan and they’ll get some new readers too! We can’t do this writing thing without you guys.  So thank you so much!  Without readers
column49: we’re just talking to ourselves.  We love and appreciate you for reading- but we need to know you’re doing it.  We need feedback like we need air.  Don’t let your favorite writers suffocate! :) " False text

column2: I made a new blog @yoi-withthe-shit (plot twist being there is no shit) to combat the recent surge of hate. I wanted to share all the content the fandom makes and just be nice to all the creators. There are actual human people behind each blog and they took their time to create good shit and frankly everyone needs a little more recognition.Everything on this blog will be tagged to make blacklisting easier and keep people’s dashes free of content they don’t want to see.  If y’all don’t mind
column3: please reblog this post to share the good news that is Being Kind to Others!  " False text

column1: dystopiansushi 158830925498 "2017-03-26 00:14:07 GMT" http://dystopiansushi.tumblr.com/post/158830925498/winter-song-ch-16-by-proantagonist "borntomake: 106
column2: 190 words. Victor/Yuuri. Explicit. Canon compliant. Slow build. Switching. Fills in the gaps between episodes 7-12. (And beyond.) With the final Grand Prix performance of the season now behind him
column3: Yuuri soon found himself faced with a new kind of horror.If there was anything he was dreading more about this trip than the competition itself
column4: it was without a doubt the annual ISU banquet. Yet here he was. In a stuffy room filled with stuffy people with nothing to do but gossip
column6: and make Yuuri feel self-conscious. No wonder he’d sought refuge in a bottle of champagne last year.The gathering was held in one of the banquet halls on the first floor of their hotel
column7: and the décor was quite different than last year. Warmer and more inviting
column8: with wood paneled walls and a softly lit chandelier overhead that glittered with hundreds of crystals. Though the room was reasonably comfortable in size
column9: it was an intimate space to share with so many guests.Yuuri’s memories of the banquet in Sochi were still fuzzy
column10: but he was certain he had embarrassed himself thoroughly enough that he didn’t want to see any of these people ever again. He’d begged Victor not to make him go
column11: only to be answered with a tearful response of: “But the banquet is where our love story began.”Victor could be unbearably dramatic at times.Read the full story on AO3" False link
